articles.title: Indigenous digital activists in Mexico assert their self-determination with regard to artificial intelligence
articles.summary: What does artificial intelligence mean for Mexico's Indigenous languages? For two days, digital activists reflected on how these technologies can revitalize or threaten their languages and cultures.
articles.content:
What impact does artificial intelligence (AI) have on Mexico's Indigenous languages? This was one of the questions posed at the first AI+Indigenous Languages Forum, held on March 13 and 14 in Mexico City. The forum provided an opportunity to hear the aspirations and concerns of dozens of participants, explore how tools like machine translation, text-to-speech, and chatbots work, and reflect on linguistic sovereignty and data governance.

With the participation of 47 activists speaking more than 20 different Indigenous languages in Mexico, who are all developing projects that use digital tools to support Indigenous languages, the forum provided a space to share concerns and explore common principles without seeking a unified, collective position.

Held within the framework of the Indigenous Languages Digital Activists Summit 2025, the forum was organized by Rising Voices in collaboration with First Languages AI Reality (FLAIR) and the Research Chair in Digital Indigeneities at Bishop's University in Canada. The event was supported by the W.K. Kellogg Foundation, the Embassy of Canada in Mexico, and the Wikimedia Foundation, with the Cultural Center of Spain in Mexico as the host.

Key questions were asked: Who is using AI in relation to Indigenous languages? What risks and opportunities exist for peoples’ sovereignty? How can we collectively protect cultural heritage and intellectual creativity? Are these technologies aligned with my values?

Reflections on the risks of AI

Central topics of discussion included copyright, environmental impact, collective rights, cultural heritage, and monitoring of the extraction of ancestral knowledge. Participant Katia González voiced a shared concern about the environmental impact of artificial intelligence requirements:



En mi opinión, parte de la congruencia ambiental es cuestionarnos los impactos que está teniendo en nuestras comunidades para mantener el enfriamiento de los motores.

In my opinion, part of environmental consistency is questioning the impacts it's having on our communities to keep our engines cool.

Linguistic and cultural sovereignty was also a hot topic, with concerns over whether the development of generative AI could affect the self-determination of Indigenous communities, their collective rights, and intellectual property rights over their knowledge and cultural expressions. The importance of respecting communities’ autonomy regarding access to and use of their knowledge was also highlighted, as was the need for inclusive regulatory frameworks and policies that prioritize the protection of human rights and cultural diversity.

Significant ethical and technical challenges related to the use of artificial intelligence were also addressed, such as lack of technological knowledge, surveillance risks, and digital divides.

Participants also discussed the need to question how content is collected and presented in order to avoid biases and stereotypes. The data that feeds AI comes from external, biased, incomplete, and outdated perspectives, which distorts the cultural richness and current realities of Indigenous peoples.

Forum participant Verónica Aguilar stated:

¿De dónde saca sus datos la inteligencia artificial para crear un contenido nuevo? Pues de lo que ya existe. Y lo que ya existe es mucho de lo que se promovió en el siglo pasado, muy folclorizante. La historia de los indígenas en el campo, de que todos somos buenos. Entonces, de ahí va a tomar la IA la información. Y quizás, desde el punto de vista lingüístico, [el uso de la IA] es algo positivo, pero desde el punto de vista de los valores que están transmitiendo, ahí no vamos a estar de acuerdo porque para nosotros no es sólo un asunto de lengua sino de toda la cultura.

Where does artificial intelligence get its data to create new content? Well, from what already exists. And what already exists is much of what was promoted in the last century, very folkloric. The history of Indigenous people in the countryside, that we are all good. So, that's where AI will take its information from. And perhaps, from a linguistic perspective, [the use of AI] is something positive, but from the perspective of the values being transmitted, we won't agree on that because for us it's not just a matter of language but of the entire culture.

On the second day of the forum, dialogue highlighting the need to establish fundamental principles for the development of AI, and addressing risks such as gender bias, algorithmic perspectives, and the inclusion of Indigenous communities, brought together government actors, companies, NGOs, and embassies.

AI applications with Indigenous languages

AI also offers opportunities for Indigenous peoples. For example, Dani Ramos, a Nahua student in computer science and linguistics, presented examples of AI applications using Indigenous languages in the United States, Canada, and New Zealand, created with and by Indigenous peoples.

She highlighted the example of Te Hiku Media in Aotearoa (New Zealand), which uses technology to revitalize the Māori language, as well as the Indigenous and Artificial Intelligence Protocol, which guarantees data sovereignty and community participation. Projects such as Abundant Intelligences, which promotes AI models based on Indigenous knowledge, were also mentioned, alongside similar initiatives in Latin America.

The cases of the Lakota AI Code Camp, IndigiGenius, and FLAIR, which seek to empower communities through technological tools designed from their own cultural and linguistic perspectives, were also shared. These efforts reflect a global movement defending the right of Indigenous peoples to shape AI according to their needs and values.

A desired future

Following an exercise on envisioning the future, participants were divided into small groups and asked to work on proposals for technological development based on Indigenous autonomy, as well as on promoting the creation and management of artificial intelligence, digital tools, and multilingual platforms managed by Indigenous speakers.

The need for inclusive technologies like search engines, voice agents, and automatic translation devices in Indigenous languages was highlighted, allowing communities to develop their own applications without depending on large companies. The importance of preserving Indigenous cultures through digital repositories, community media, and new maps based on their territorial vision was also emphasized.

The creation of intercultural networks, technological cooperatives, and technological sovereignty with their own programming languages was proposed, as part of imagining a sustainable future that combines digital technologies with respect for the land and autonomous local management.

In terms of action, participants suggested the strengthening of digital activists’ networks, the promotion of technological autonomy, the safe use of AI and data sovereignty, the promotion of legislative proposals and campaigns for the ethical use of AI, and the development of collaborative workshops for recommendations adapted to Indigenous contexts. Everyone agreed that this forum should be the beginning of a community-based, participatory strategy with a tangible impact.

Participants recognized the need to continue the dialogue in order to create appropriate tools and protocols for Indigenous communities in the context of the development of AI and language technologies — especially given the complexity that AI poses regarding autonomy, collective ownership, the preservation of linguistic variants, and the predominance of Western perspectives.

As a space in which Indigenous digital activists in Mexico could critically reflect on and analyze the effects of AI, the forum was an important first step — a launching pad to begin to imagine digital ecosystems led by Indigenous speakers who protect and revitalize their languages with a vision for the future.

This represents a meaningful positive step toward empowering Indigenous communities in the digital age.
articles.personality_title: Indigenous activists in Mexico lead the way to protect languages with AI
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Indigenous languages in Mexico face challenges and opportunities as artificial intelligence (AI) technologies grow. Activists worry about how AI might affect their cultures, rights, and language survival.

**What happened** – On March 13 and 14, Mexico City hosted the first AI+Indigenous Languages Forum. Forty-seven digital activists, speaking over 20 Indigenous languages, gathered to discuss how AI tools like translation and chatbots could help or harm their communities. The event was organized by Rising Voices with partners from Canada and supported by several foundations and embassies.

**Impact** – The forum gave Indigenous activists a chance to share concerns about AI’s environmental effects, cultural rights, and biased data that misrepresents their people. It also highlighted projects worldwide where Indigenous groups use AI to revive languages, showing that technology can support cultural survival when communities lead its use. This event marks a unique step toward Indigenous control over digital tools and knowledge.

**What's next step** – Participants want to keep working together to build AI technologies that respect Indigenous values and languages. They plan to create networks, promote laws for ethical AI, and develop digital tools managed by Indigenous speakers. The forum is seen as the start of a community-led strategy to protect languages and culture in the digital world.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Indigenous digital activists in Mexico are shaping the future of AI to revive and protect their languages while asserting control over their cultural knowledge.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des activistes autochtones au Mexique utilisent l'IA pour protéger leurs langues
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les langues autochtones au Mexique sont confrontées à des défis et des opportunités avec le développement de l'intelligence artificielle (IA). Les activistes s'inquiètent de l'impact de l'IA sur leurs cultures, leurs droits et la survie de leurs langues.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Les 13 et 14 mars, Mexico a accueilli le premier Forum IA+Langues Autochtones. Quarante-sept activistes numériques, parlant plus de 20 langues autochtones, se sont réunis pour discuter de la manière dont les outils d'IA comme la traduction et les chatbots pourraient aider ou nuire à leurs communautés. L'événement a été organisé par Rising Voices en collaboration avec des partenaires canadiens et soutenu par plusieurs fondations et ambassades.

**Impact** – Le forum a permis aux activistes autochtones d'exprimer leurs inquiétudes sur les effets environnementaux de l'IA, les droits culturels et les données biaisées qui déforment leur réalité. Il a aussi mis en lumière des projets mondiaux où les peuples autochtones utilisent l'IA pour revitaliser leurs langues, montrant que la technologie peut soutenir la survie culturelle quand les communautés en prennent le contrôle. Cet événement marque une étape unique vers la maîtrise indigène des outils numériques et du savoir.

**Prochaines étapes** – Les participants souhaitent continuer à collaborer pour créer des technologies d'IA respectueuses des valeurs et des langues autochtones. Ils prévoient de construire des réseaux, promouvoir des lois pour une IA éthique, et développer des outils numériques gérés par des locuteurs autochtones. Le forum est vu comme le début d'une stratégie communautaire pour protéger les langues et la culture dans le monde numérique.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les activistes numériques autochtones du Mexique façonnent l'avenir de l'IA pour revitaliser et protéger leurs langues tout en affirmant le contrôle de leur savoir culturel.
articles.personality_title_es: Activistas indígenas en México lideran la protección de sus lenguas con IA
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Las lenguas indígenas en México enfrentan retos y oportunidades con el avance de la inteligencia artificial (IA). Los activistas están preocupados por cómo la IA podría afectar sus culturas, derechos y la supervivencia de sus idiomas.

**Qué pasó** – El 13 y 14 de marzo, Ciudad de México fue sede del primer Foro IA+Lenguas Indígenas. Cuarenta y siete activistas digitales, que hablan más de 20 lenguas indígenas, se reunieron para discutir cómo herramientas de IA como la traducción automática y los chatbots pueden ayudar o dañar a sus comunidades. El evento fue organizado por Rising Voices con socios de Canadá y apoyado por varias fundaciones y embajadas.

**Impacto** – El foro permitió a los activistas indígenas compartir preocupaciones sobre impactos ambientales de la IA, derechos culturales y datos sesgados que distorsionan su realidad. También destacó proyectos globales donde pueblos indígenas usan la IA para revivir sus idiomas, demostrando que la tecnología puede apoyar la supervivencia cultural cuando las comunidades lideran su uso. Este evento es un paso importante hacia el control indígena de las herramientas digitales y el conocimiento.

**Próximos pasos** – Los participantes quieren seguir trabajando juntos para crear tecnologías de IA que respeten los valores y lenguas indígenas. Planean formar redes, promover leyes para un uso ético de la IA y desarrollar herramientas digitales gestionadas por hablantes indígenas. El foro es visto como el inicio de una estrategia comunitaria para proteger lenguas y cultura en el mundo digital.

**Frase clave** – Activistas digitales indígenas en México están moldeando el futuro de la IA para revivir y proteger sus lenguas mientras afirman el control de su conocimiento cultural.

articles.title: The European Union and the Council of Europe in BiH continue activities within the initiative ‘Block Hate. Share Love!’
articles.summary: By launching the second phase of the initiative "Block Hate. Share Love! 2.0" in Vukosavlje, the European Union and the Council of Europe promoted diversity, equality, and inclusion through a children's football tournament.
articles.content:
By launching the second phase of the initiative “Block Hate. Share Love! 2.0” in Vukosavlje, the European Union and the Council of Europe promoted diversity, equality, and inclusion through a children’s football tournament.

Sarajevo, (Fena) – The second phase of the joint initiative of the European Union and the Council of Europe “Block Hate. Share Love! 2.0” officially began on Thursday, August 21, with a children’s football tournament at the FK Sloga stadium in Vukosavlje, where boys and girls from five municipalities gathered to promote diversity, equality, and inclusion.

Cheering from the stands, colorful banners with messages of friendship, and mixed teams of boys and girls on the field turned the FK Sloga stadium into a celebration of diversity and inclusion.

Young players from Vukosavlje, Modriča, Šamac, Brod, and Odžak were divided into mixed teams named Tolerance, Equality, Respect, Diversity, Solidarity, and Inclusion, showing that, both on and off the field, unity and respect always win.

The event was opened by the Mayor of Vukosavlje, Zekerijah Bahić, who welcomed the initiative in his municipality.

– I strive to make Vukosavlje a place where every child can thrive and never become a victim of hate speech. Sport has the power to unite us across all boundaries, such as gender, ethnicity, skin color, disability, and other identities – said Bahić.

The Assistant Minister for Human Rights and Refugees of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kemo Sarač, emphasized that respecting diversity is one of the first conditions for understanding, appreciating, and respecting human rights and fundamental freedoms.

– The more we are willing to adapt ourselves in terms of respecting another person, the more we are ready for a democratic society – pointed out Sarač.

The expert advisor for European integration and international cooperation in sports at the Ministry of Civil Affairs of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Adis Osmanović, confirmed the Ministry’s commitment to promoting unity, tolerance, and mutual respect as fundamental values that define the true spirit of sports.

– Together we can protect the integrity of sports and harness its unparalleled power to enhance peace, cooperation, and national pride – said Osmanović.

According to Ajna Karić from the women’s football club Odžak 102, girls are certainly capable of playing football, and she is glad that the village of Jakeš managed to host such a gathering. (22.08.)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a meaningful initiative promoting diversity, equality, and inclusion through a children’s football tournament involving multiple municipalities. It highlights positive social values such as tolerance and respect, with broad societal impact by fostering unity and combating hate speech among youth. The story is focused, detailed, and involves public officials endorsing human rights principles.
articles.personality_title: Children’s football tournament promotes diversity and respect in Bosnia and Herzegovina
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union and the Council of Europe have been working together in Bosnia and Herzegovina to fight hate and promote positive values like diversity, equality, and inclusion.

**What happened** – On August 21, 2024, the second phase of their project called “Block Hate. Share Love! 2.0” began with a children’s football tournament in Vukosavlje. Boys and girls from five nearby towns played together in mixed teams named after values such as Tolerance, Equality, and Respect. The Mayor of Vukosavlje and other officials spoke about the importance of sports to bring people together.

**Impact** – This event showed that sports can help children learn to respect each other, no matter their background or differences. It also sends a message against hate speech and encourages young people to build friendships based on understanding and kindness.

**What's next step** – The initiative will continue with more activities to promote these values across the region. Officials hope this will lead to stronger community bonds and greater respect for human rights.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A children’s football tournament in Bosnia and Herzegovina is helping young players and their communities celebrate diversity and stand against hate through teamwork and respect.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un tournoi de football pour enfants promeut la diversité et le respect en Bosnie-Herzégovine
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Union européenne et le Conseil de l’Europe collaborent en Bosnie-Herzégovine pour lutter contre la haine et promouvoir des valeurs positives comme la diversité, l’égalité et l’inclusion.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 21 août 2024, la deuxième phase de leur projet « Bloquez la haine. Partagez l’amour ! 2.0 » a commencé par un tournoi de football pour enfants à Vukosavlje. Des garçons et des filles de cinq communes voisines ont joué ensemble dans des équipes mixtes portant des noms de valeurs comme Tolérance, Égalité et Respect. Le maire de Vukosavlje et d’autres responsables ont souligné l’importance du sport pour rassembler les gens.

**Impact** – Cet événement a montré que le sport peut aider les enfants à apprendre à se respecter, quelles que soient leurs différences. Il envoie aussi un message contre les discours de haine et encourage les jeunes à construire des amitiés basées sur la compréhension et la gentillesse.

**Prochaine étape** – L’initiative continuera avec d’autres activités pour promouvoir ces valeurs dans la région. Les responsables espèrent que cela renforcera les liens communautaires et le respect des droits humains.

**Phrase clé** – Un tournoi de football pour enfants en Bosnie-Herzégovine aide les jeunes joueurs et leurs communautés à célébrer la diversité et à lutter contre la haine grâce au travail d’équipe et au respect.
articles.personality_title_es: Torneo infantil de fútbol promueve la diversidad y el respeto en Bosnia y Herzegovina
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea y el Consejo de Europa trabajan juntos en Bosnia y Herzegovina para combatir el odio y fomentar valores positivos como la diversidad, la igualdad y la inclusión.

**Qué pasó** – El 21 de agosto de 2024 comenzó la segunda fase del proyecto llamado «Bloquea el odio. Comparte amor 2.0» con un torneo de fútbol infantil en Vukosavlje. Niños y niñas de cinco municipios cercanos jugaron juntos en equipos mixtos con nombres que representan valores como Tolerancia, Igualdad y Respeto. El alcalde de Vukosavlje y otros funcionarios destacaron la importancia del deporte para unir a las personas.

**Impacto** – Este evento demostró que el deporte puede ayudar a los niños a aprender a respetarse, sin importar sus diferencias. También envía un mensaje contra el discurso de odio y anima a los jóvenes a formar amistades basadas en el entendimiento y la amabilidad.

**Próximo paso** – La iniciativa continuará con más actividades para promover estos valores en la región. Los funcionarios esperan que esto fortalezca los lazos comunitarios y el respeto por los derechos humanos.

**Frase clave** – Un torneo infantil de fútbol en Bosnia y Herzegovina ayuda a los jóvenes jugadores y a sus comunidades a celebrar la diversidad y a oponerse al odio mediante el trabajo en equipo y el respeto.
